subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US and Chinese officials are still discussing when their leaders can meet to sign off on a trade deal and a meeting date could be announced as soon as Thursday, according to sources familiar with the plans. (Newswires)

US Agriculture Secretary Perdue says US-China trade talks are down to the last few days. Perdue also commented that the US wants binding China pledges which are enforced by tariffs with a target of 2025 for China to meet trade pledges, while the US also wants a timetable for China purchases and market access. (Newswires)

US NEC Director Kudlow said that we are not there yet on a deal with China but hope to get closer this week, while he also commented that no decisions have been made yet regarding potential auto tariffs as the 90-day review period could be extended. (Newswires)

China's State Council said they will further reduce government related fees & services charges to reduce the burden on Co's and individuals, to take effect on July 1st, according to state media. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK lawmakers voted (313 ayes vs. 312 noes) to approve the European Union Withdrawal Bill which requires UK PM May to seek an extension to Article 50 to prevent a no-deal Brexit. In terms of the amendments, UK parliament rejected the Benn Amendment which which would have held indicative votes on Monday after a tie of (310 vs. 310) and rejected Amendment 1 (123 ayes vs. 488 noes) which was tabled by Brexiteers and would have seeked to ensure Brexit occurs before May 22. (Newswires)

UK PM May will reportedly pave the way for a longer extension next week in the event she cannot secure her deal and the UK would participate in European Parliament elections in that scenario, according to a Telegraph reporter. (Telegraph)

BoE's Carney said the risk of a no-deal is alarmingly high in which he warned could happen by accident and said that suggestions a no-deal could be managed are absolute nonsense. Furthermore, BoE's Carney said he will do everything to support the economy in the event of a no-deal Brexit but suggested the financial sector was not among the worries in a no-deal scenario, while he added that he would absolutely not stay in his post past the planned January 2020 departure. (Newswires/Sky News)

UK Attorney General Cox said a customs union was "not desirable" but would accept it if it was the only way to leave the EU. (BBC)

There were initial reports that UK opposition Labour leader Corbyn said talks with PM May went "very well" and expects more talks with the PM soon according to Daily Mirror's Pippa Crerar. However, there were later reports citing UK government sources that talks with Labour were not as productive as previously stated in which one source suggested it "did not go well". (Twitter/BuzzFeed)

  • UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Mar) 48.9 vs. Exp. 50.9 (Prev. 51.3). (Newswires) 
  • EU Markit Services Final PMI (Mar) 53.3 vs. Exp. 52.7 (Prev. 52.7) 
  • EU Markit Comp Final PMI (Mar) 51.6 vs. Exp. 51.3 (Prev. 51.3) 
  • EU Retail Sales (Feb) M/M 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 1.3%, Rev. 0.9%) 
  • EU Retail Sales (Feb) Y/Y 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.3% (Prev. 2.2%) 

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 7.238M vs. Exp. -0.425M (Prev. 2.8M). (Newswires)

Russia is to reach the output cut level agreed with OPEC+ in April, according to reports citing Energy Minister Novak. (RIA)

Libyan authorities have declared general military alert after Eastern Libyan forces said they are moving west. (Newswires) 

US

US administration officials are said to have studied border closing options regarding the US/Mexico border in which options include a partial shutdown, while there were comments from White House spokeswoman Schlapp that progress has been made on the Mexico border issue. (Newswires)

  • US ADP National Employment (Mar) 129.0k vs. Exp. 170.0k (Prev. 183.0k, Rev. 197k) 
  • US ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 56.1 vs. Exp. 58.0 (Prev. 59.7) 
  • US Markit Services PMI (Mar F) 55.3 (Prev. 54.8) 
  • US Markit Comp PMI (Mar F) 54.6 (Prev. 54.3)

 

MARKET RECAP

Chipmakers were the star performing sector on Wednesday, where AMD (AMD) lead the pack after a bullish outlook article in DigiTimes, in addition to receiving a positive mention at Nomura; the likes of Intel (INTC), Micron (MU) and Nvidia (NVDA) also followed suit. Verizon (VZ) caught a bid as it rolled out its new 5G mobile network. Caterpillar (CAT) and Raytheon (RTN) opened lower after downgrades at Deutsche Bank and UBS respectively. Nielsen (NLSN) traded higher after reports a final bidding offer had been made for it by a buyout firm. Urban Outfitters (URBN) surged on an upgrade at DA Davidson. Boeing (BA) traded lower following Baird saying it expects Wall Street to lower its EPS estimates for the co. following the 737 MAX jet crashes. Game Stop (GME) nosedived after disappointing earnings and guidance. SPX +0.2% at 2873, NDX +0.6% at 7545, DJI +0.2% at 26218.

The constructive risk environment resulted in higher yields. The usual suspects -- optimism about the prospects of a China/US trade deal, less chance of no deal Brexit, decent services PMIs out of china and Europe, and a decent retail sales report out of the latter -- were cited, and the TPLEX was happy to look through a sub-par ADP report, and a mixed non-manufacturing ISM. Indeed, growth concerns have ebbed slightly, which is also reflected in the 3m/10yr spread remaining positive. Major curve spreads were a touch steeper. US T-note futures (M9) settled 8+ lower at 123-16.

subject: Amendment 22 rejected by UK Parliament (400 vs. 220), MPs now voting on Amendment 1
analysis_details:
Amendment 1 which was tabled by Brexiteers imposes a firm Brexit deadline by saying that the Prime Minister could not agree to a delay beyond May 22.

Amendment 22 which was tabled by the government seeks to ensure that the Bill does not limit the powers that a Minister of the Crown would otherwise have to seek, or agree to, an extension of the Article 50 period.

subject: UK Parliament update: Cooper-Letwin Bill Amendment 21 was defeated by (313 vs. 304), while Amendment 22 is currently being voted on
analysis_details:
Amendment 21 would delete part of the bill which states that if the PM asks for an extension date and the EU made a counter offer, she would then have to ask MPs to agree it the next day.

Amendment 22 seeks to ensure that the Bill does not limit the powers that a Minister of the Crown would otherwise have to seek, or agree to, an extension of the Article 50 period.

US MARKET WRAP 3 April 2019: Risk-on fades after mixed ISM, ADP miss
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities mixed, dollar down, Treasuries down, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: Decent Caixin PMIs, EZ PMIs spark risk-on; enthusiasm curbed by mixed ISM, ADP miss.

* AHEAD: German Industrial Orders; ECB Minutes; US Initial Jobless Claims; RBI Rate Decision; Fed's Williams, Mester & Harker Speaking; Supply from Spain & France; US 3,10 & 30yr Refunding Announcement.

* TRADE: NEC Director Kudlow leaned slightly on the optimistic trade headlines which have landed over the last few days, stating that "we are not there on a deal" but hope to get closer this week. He also said that no decision has been made on potential auto tariffs, and the 90-day review period could be extended. Earlier in the session, the US Ag Sec Perdue said talks were down to the last few days. In later trade, reports suggested that the US wanted binding China pledges which are enforced by tariffs, with a target of 2025 for China to meet trade pledges; US also wants timetable for China purchases and market access.

* ADP PAYROLLS: ADP reported 129k payrolls were added to the US economy in March, disappointing the consensus looking for 175k. Pantheon Macroeconomics reminds us that ADP's model incorporates prior official payroll data as well as information from firms which use its payroll processing services, so it’s possible that the fluke 25K private payroll number for February pulled down the March ADP. "Frustratingly, the influence of the prior month’s official numbers is impossible to isolate consistently in advance," Pantheon writes, "usually, the effect of weak official numbers on the next ADP reading is seen in the month after severe weather events -- February's survey week was much colder than January's, relative to seasonal norms -- and typically the official number for the month after the weather event is stronger than ADP." Pantheon goes on to say that the first alternative story, in which ADP has captured a real downshift in payroll growth, cannot be ruled out, "but is very hard to square with the survey evidence and the newly-revised, lower, jobless claims numbers," and "the final possibility is that greater-than-usual snow cover in March, relative to February -- adjusted for seasonal norms -- hit March payrolls, despite only modestly colder-than-usual temperatures," and the uncertainty here is huge, "so prudence dictates that we nudge down our forecast for the official number to about 160K from 180K, but this is a very tricky call."

* ISM NON-MANUFACTURING: The non-manufacturing ISM was a mixed bag, with the headline falling to a 19-month low (56.1 vs exp 58.0 and prev. 59.7). Business activity and new orders fell, though employment rose after a large slip in February. However, Oxford Economics said it remains encouraged by the details of the report that paint a rather healthy and stable picture of the services sector at the end of Q1: "Non-manufacturing activity is now consistent with a healthy but moderating economic momentum, with the average in the first quarter at 57.5 compared with 59.5 in Q4 2018," the consultancy said, "in fact, the March downshift in services activity to a more reasonable pace is in line with our expectations for economic growth to gradually cool to around 2.0% y/y by the end of 2019," it adds.

* BREXIT: UK lawmakers will vote on the Cooper/Letwin bill at 2200 BST; the Bill aims to block a no deal Brexit, despite the fact that such a legal assurance would need to also be agreed by the EU as well. From the bloc's perspective, EU President Juncker on Wednesday said that UK Parliament must approve the Withdrawal Agreement by next Friday if it wanted another short extension to the Article 50 Brexit process (EU policymakers will, in fact, need to see an outline of what the UK wants by 10 April, in order to deliberate on the details before the emergency EU meeting on 12 April). Talks between the UK government and the opposition Labour Party have begun, and will continue on Thursday; there has been little concrete progress, though commentary was generally constructive; however, in late trade, sources said that talks with Labour were not as “constructive” as had been claimed.

* WTI (K9) SETTLES $0.12 LOWER AT $62.46; BRENT (M9) SETTLES $0.06 LOWER AT $69.31. The oil complex traded firm in early trade, underpinned by news that US/China talks were making solid progress on the demand-side, while reports continue to focus on the OPEC supply cut pact on the supply-side which are tightening the market; Russia will reportedly reach the output cut level it agreed with OPEC in April, its energy minister said. The complex was also happy to look through Tuesday's API inventory data, which showed a surprise build. However, the complex found it more difficult to ignore the weekly DOE inventory data, which showed a surprise build larger than that reported by the API (crude +7.2mln, Cushing +0.2mln, distillates -2.0mln, gasoline -1.8mln). Elsewhere, Kuwait is assessing damage at its Mina Abdullah refinery (270k BPD) after a fire. Traders were also continuing to focus on Aramco's bond prospectus released on Tuesday, which showed lower production capacity from the Ghawar oilfield, the world's largest conventional oilfield; "While Aramco did not revise down official production capacity of 12mb/d, the greater proportion of spare capacity attributable to Saudi’s long tail of smaller fields will raise questions about how realistic the capacity figure is," UBS said. Looking ahead, the bank believes that oil prices will continue to be supported in Q2 by gradually pricing in sentiment and supportive fundamentals.

* SPX +0.2% at 2873, NDX +0.6% at 7545, DJI +0.2% at 26218. SECTORS: Energy -1.0%, Materials +1.3%, Industrials -0.3%, Cons Discretionary +0.7%, Cons Staples -0.6%, Healthcare -0.1%, Financials +0.3%, Tech +0.8%, Telecoms +0.4%, Utilities -0.2%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Chipmakers were the star performing sector on Wednesday, where AMD (AMD) lead the pack after a bullish outlook article in DigiTimes, in addition to receiving a positive mention at Nomura; the likes of Intel (INTC), Micron (MU) and Nvidia (NVDA) also followed suit. Verizon (VZ) caught a bid as it rolled out its new 5G mobile network. Caterpillar (CAT) and Raytheon (RTN) opened lower after downgrades at Deutsche Bank and UBS respectively. Nielsen (NLSN) traded higher after reports a final bidding offer had been made for it by a buyout firm. Urban Outfitters (URBN) surged on an upgrade at DA Davidson. Boeing (BA) traded lower following Baird saying it expects Wall Street to lower its EPS estimates for the co. following the 737 MAX jet crashes. Game Stop (GME) nosedived after disappointing earnings and guidance.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLES 8+ LOWER AT 123-16. The constructive risk environment resulted in higher yields. The usual suspects -- optimism about the prospects of a China/US trade deal, less chance of no deal Brexit, decent services PMIs out of china and Europe, and a decent retail sales report out of the latter -- were cited, and the TPLEX was happy to look through a sub-par ADP report, and a mixed non-manufacturing ISM. Indeed, growth concerns have ebbed slightly, which is also reflected in the 3m/10yr spread remaining positive. Major curve spreads were a touch steeper.

* FX WRAP: The Buck was lower amid risk-on (see USD section below). EUR was higher amid the USD weakness, while some bargain hunting was cited after reasonable data (PMI and retail sales). GBP was higher, despite lawmakers rejecting a plan to hold more indicative votes on Monday; traders await the outcome of the Cooper/Letwin motion to rule out no deal Brexit (results expected around 2200 BST), and are generally encouraged by May's cross-party approach (see below). Aussie traded up on a combination of retail sales beating overnight, China data continuing to show stabilisation, iron ore prices jumping higher, as well as the overall constructive risk tone. RUB could not participate in the EMFX rally, with US Senators reintroducing a Russian sanctions bill. TRY also could not participate in the EMFX rally, with US Vice President Pence. The national emergency in the US has seen strong rhetoric towards Mexico, which today weighed on the MXN (see below for detailed analysis). 

* USD, EMFX: A risk-on environment resulted in the DXY trading negative. Some have wondered how much the buck is being swayed by the bouts of risk-on seen in recent weeks, given the moves seem relatively benign. However, analysts have noted that the US maintains a relative yield attraction, and thus, other major G10 FX might struggle to make ground against the buck. However, Morgan Stanley takes the more negative view: "We want to make it clear that now is the time to sell the USD as we see China rebounding economically, which should soon spill over into better EM growth," the bank writes. It also points out that there are now signs that the Brexit impasse could be overcome, which reduces the possibility of no deal - that could help to support business sentiment in Europe, the bank argues, which could help the EUR to make ground against the USD. The bank also says that EMFX action will play a pivotal role, noting that the EMFX complex has remained resilient while DXY has tried to rally. "The relative strength of EM is telling, suggesting that the next big move for EM FX is on the upside," Morgan Stanley writes, "EUR and JPY still see funding-related outflows, which also support EM." And it is this reason why the moderate EURUSD weakness is not concerning the EMFX complex, MS says. "We reiterate that EURUSD should hold 1.1170 and USDJPY should fail to break 111.70/80 with market participants seeing the US economy losing its outperforming status."

* GBP: Some food for thought provided by the folks at SocGen, which notes that post the GFC up to 2016, there was a strong positive correlation between EURGBP and EURUSD, though that collapsed in the middle of 2016, it has recovered, albeit it is weaker than before the UK voted to exit the EU. The bank points out that in the period between the ECB's adoption of negative rates and QE at the start of 2015, and the referendum, EURUSD average 1.1060 and EURGBP averaged 0.74. "Today, the gilt/Bund yield differential is back where it was pre-referendum, but EURGBP is trading over 10% higher than you might have expected, ex-referendum," SocGen writes, "this kind of exercise has its limits, but while Prime Minister’s cross-party move could deliver a massive schism in her party, it could also deliver a 'softer' Brexit than her proposed deal." The bank notes that EURGBP could fall to 0.80, and GBPUSD rise towards 1.45 in a deal/soft Brexit scenario, while a 'no-deal' could see EURGBP rise to the 0.90-0.95 region, while GBPUSD could fall back into the 1.15-1.20 bracket; however, "because the market has been bearish since the referendum, we get a quick response to any 'soft' political news," rather than the harder variety.

* MXN: UBS has warned MXN pairs are primed for unwind; the bank notes that US President Trump has in recent days upped his threats against Mexico to shut the southern border to stem the migrant crisis, and UBS also thinks there are risks that Congress will not ratify the USMCA deal. "If anyone was looking for a potential catalyst for MXN weakness, I think that [Trump's recent comments] could be it. Trump has walked this commentary back over the past few days, perhaps because his team has reportedly tried to explain that shutting every border crossing would have a crippling knock-on effect to the economies of US border states," but with that said, UBS notes that the migrant issue is not going to go away. But UBS sees more risks on that the USMCA agreement will not be ratified: "The market has assumed this is a done deal, when it most definitely is NOT. Back in the summer of 2018, when the US and Mexico were finalizing the trade negotiations, MXN rallied by over 12% against the USD, in what was largely a broad USD-stronger environment (as well as some unwind of the market's AMLO election fears)." UBS warns that if the deal falls apart, downside risks could be significant; bookies' odds imply the deal has around 30% chance of being ratified - it was at over 80% at the start of the year. "Nancy Pelosi is unlikely to give Trump a win on trade this year, and even more unlikely in the 2020 election year, so it is understandable that the chance this passes the House is cratering by the day."

Traders were also continuing to focus on Aramco's bond prospectus released on Tuesday, which showed lower production capacity from the Ghawar oilfield, the world's largest conventional oilfield; "While Aramco did not revise down official production capacity of 12mb/d, the greater proportion of spare capacity attributable to Saudi’s long tail of smaller fields will raise questions about how realistic the capacity figure is," UBS said. Looking ahead, the bank believes that oil prices will continue to be supported in Q2 by gradually pricing in sentiment and supportive fundamentals.

ANALYSIS: UBS warns on MXN downside
analysis_details: UBS has warned MXN pairs are primed for unwind; the bank notes that US President Trump has in recent days upped his threats against Mexico to shut the southern border to stem the migrant crisis, and UBS also thinks there are risks that Congress will not ratify the USMCA deal. "If anyone was looking for a potential catalyst for MXN weakness, I think that [Trump's recent comments] could be it. Trump has walked this commentary back over the past few days, perhaps because his team has reportedly tried to explain that shutting every border crossing would have a crippling knock-on effect to the economies of US border states," but with that said, UBS notes that the migrant issue is not going to go away. But UBS sees more risks on that the USMCA agreement will not be ratified: "The market has assumed this is a done deal, when it most definitely is NOT. Back in the summer of 2018, when the US and Mexico were finalizing the trade negotiations, MXN rallied by over 12% against the USD, in what was largely a broad USD-stronger environment (as well as some unwind of the market's AMLO election fears)." UBS warns that if the deal falls apart, downside risks could be significant; bookies' odds imply the deal has around 30% chance of being ratified - it was at over 80% at the start of the year. "Nancy Pelosi is unlikely to give Trump a win on trade this year, and even more unlikely in the 2020 election year, so it is understandable that the chance this passes the House is cratering by the day."

subject: UK lawmakers vote in favour of allowing an attempt to pass legislation to prevent 'no deal' Brexit; Ayes 312 vs 311 nays
Conservative and Labour teams to meet again for detailed talks, though there was no decisive shift from Downing St this afternoon, BBC reporter says
(UPDATE) BREXIT ANALYSIS: WHAT NOW?
content:
*TODAY’S SCHEDULE [BST]

  • 17:00 - MPs vote on whether Letwin/Cooper bill will be voted on tonight
  • 18:00 - Potential emergency Shadow Cabinet meeting
  • 19:00 – Key vote on Letwin/Cooper bill (on the second reading)
  • 22:00 – Final vote on Letwin/Cooper bill (on the third reading)

N.B. PM May will not be going to the 1922 Committee meeting tonight (Trade Secretary Fox will be going instead)

*LATEST: Last night, Theresa May said the UK will need a further extension of A50 to ensure it leaves in a timely way with a deal and will try to complete legislation by May 22nd. She added that she is taking action to break the logjam and offered to sit down with opposition Labour leader Corbyn to hopefully reach a solution that delivers on the referendum and if they cannot agree on a single unified approach, they could agree on a set of arrangements to put to the house and that the government would abide by Parliament’s decision. The labour leader stated he was “very happy” to conduct talks with the Premier. Number 10 are reportedly pressing to get a new deal through the House of Commons by the weekend, according to BBC’s Norman Smith.

*MAY’S PLAN:

  • Decide on a plan with the Labour party to make sure UK leaves the EU with a deal
  • Put that plan through the HoC, win approval (hopefully) and present the deal to the EU27 on April 10th
  • If the HoC cannot agree on a plan, PM proposes joint options for parliament to vote on (i.e. indicative votes)
  • Once a plan is sorted, follow up with legislation for UK to leave on 22nd May, avoiding a partake in European Parliamentary elections

*CORBYN’S STANCE: As cross-party talks commence today, Labour leader Corbyn noted that his talks with the PM will include:

  • An EU customs union and market access
  • Ensuring the Good Friday Agreement
  • Workers’ rights

N.B. Earlier today, Labour MP Long-Bailey noted that Corbyn not set red lines in discussions with PM May.

*NO-DEAL BILL:  Against the backdrop of all the above, a cross party group of MPs (led by Labour MP Cooper and Tory MP Letwin) are to later present a bill to take a no-deal Brexit off the table. The bill requires PM May to put forth a proposal to extend Article 50 beyond April 12th to avoid a no-deal crash (PM May highlighted that she would like an extension). MPs intent to force the bull through all its stages in the Commons, as it usually takes weeks/months for a bill to clear in parliament. Specifically the LETWIN/COOPER BILL is aimed at blocking a no-deal Brexit by forcing the Government to extend the Brexit process beyond April 12th. The bill is split in 3 sections;

  • Requires the UK PM to bring a motion to the HoC the day after the bill passes seeking an extension of any chosen length.
  • MPs are then free to change the date, binding the Govt.
  • If the EU responds with a different delay period, the PM must propose a fresh motion to the Commons.

The ex-head of Downing Street Legislative Affairs Da Costa believes, however, that there will not be enough time for the bill to pass prior to the emergency 10th April European Council Summit

N.B. 1 UK government could potentially accept the Cooper deal in some form, according to sources via New Statesman's Maguire

N.B. 2 In the event of a long A50 extension (end-March 2020) and the UK holding European Parliament elections, EU will likely “freeze” negotiations until the end of the year, i.e. until UK agrees WA with an amended political declaration, possibly after a general election or a referendum, according to BuzzFeed's Nardelli citing sources

*AMENDMENTS [TBC]:

  • (A) BENN : Proposes indicative votes on Monday
  • TORY MPS: Delay Brexit debate until Thursday 11th
  • TORY MPS 2: Bill can only proceed if agreed by two-thirds of MPs at the second reading

N.B. UK Conservative Lawmaker Letwin says will accept amendment (A) which provides for the possibility of more indicative votes on Monday

 

*BANK THOUGHTS: ING's base case, "remains that a long extension to the Article 50 period, perhaps lasting 9-12 months, is most likely. This would most likely contain an option to shorten the delay if the UK can approve a deal sooner."

Daily FX Wrap: midweek risk revival on multiple factors, but not all
content:
USD

The Buck remains depressed amidst a broad recovery in risk sentiment, which was only partly marred by disappointing UK and US services surveys along with a weaker than expected ADP payroll count ahead of Friday’s NFP. However, the DXY is holding around 97.000 as Dollar rivals pare some of their best gains made in the wake of a stellar Caixin PMI overnight, positive US-China trade talk updates and mostly above forecast EU services PMIs.

AUD/NZD

The Antipodean Dollars are off best levels, but still well ahead of their major counterparts on a combination of the bullish impulses listed above, and in the case of the Aussie also upbeat retail sales and trade data. Aud/Usd has formed a firmer recovery base above 0.7100 and did not get too distracted by option expiries in hefty size residing from 0.7100-10 (1.6 bn), while Nzd/Usd inched a but closer to 0.6800 with the Aud/Nzd cross holding steady just under 1.0500.

EUR/CHF/GBP/CAD 

Also heading into the end of Wednesday’s EU session down from peaks vs the Greenback, as the single currency faded only a few pips above yesterday’s 1.1250 high after the aforementioned Eurozone services PMI beats, while the Franc lost momentum ahead of 0.9950, albeit rebounding through 1.1250 vs the Euro even though SNB’s Maechler reiterated the need for negative Swiss rates and active currency market monitoring/intervention. Elsewhere, Cable retreated just a few pips shy of 1.3200 on a wave of optimism about an end to the Brexit stalemate after UK PM May turned to opposition leader Corbyn to try and forge a compromise, with a shock contraction in the services PMI also sapping some of Sterling’s strength. Note, the meeting between Tory and Labour heads is now underway and then Parliament will vote on whether yet another motion (Letwin-Cooper) should be tabled before IVs later tonight – see Ransquawk’s headline feed for more. The Loonie slipped back from circa 1.3295 highs towards 1.3330 along with oil after another unexpected US inventory build (and EIA significantly bigger than API last night), and as the pair failed to sustain declines through the 100 DMA (1.3313).

JPY

The sole G10 loser vs the Usd as the headline pair stuck mainly to the top end of a 111.57-21 range and never really troubled big option expiries just below the base at 111.15 (2.3 bn).

EM

More travails for the Try that bucked the broader recovery trend again, as Turkish CPI surpassed consensus and angst between the US and Turkey over the latter’s S-400 Russian order cranked up. Conversely, the Zar managed to shrug a weak SA services PMI and the Mxn got a welcome boost from positive US-Mexican border noises.

content:
• The bank notes that speculative players’ buying and selling remain unchanged. However, Algos like CTAs and Risk Parity funds (trend followers) are purchasing stocks at a gradual pace. The bank adds “global macro [hedge funds] and fundamental-based players are maintaining a prudent stance in following the current market rally.” Nomura notes that global macro hedge funds might have added shorts on Tuesday due to the deterioration of the US surprise index, but didn’t.
  • Nomura notes that global equity sentiment as climbed further to reach its higher level since July 2016, i.e. after the Brexit vote. However, the bank is sceptical at the pace of the improvement which they see as “too rapid, as if incorporating a complete settlement of US-China trade problem”. Nomura does note that some speculative players are less worried about a pullback in an “overly optimistic market” than FOMO.
  • “The trend of China and Asia ex-Japan’s equity markets continues to function as a predictor of future market sentiment developments. Most major hedge fund exposure to Asian stocks (ex. Japan) is neutral to slightly long.” Nomura also highlights that many speculators are bullish (both fundamentally and technically) on Asian equities.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 3rd April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European indices are firmer [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.7%] as the positive sentiment from Chinese PMI’s and US-China trade continues to drive markets; note, the FTSE 100 (U/C) is lagging on sterling strength
  • Dollar is subdued weighed on by G10 counterparts strength on the back of risk sentiment, Brexit updates & EZ PMIs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Services PMIs, US ADP National Employment, US Non-Manufacturing ISM PMI, Fed's Bostic, Barkin, George & Kashkari

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as trade optimism and Chinese PMI data helped the region shrug-off the indecisive lead from the US, where the global stock rally had stalled amid thin volumes, weak durable goods data and ahead of upcoming risk events. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were positive with Australia led by miners amid strength in iron ore prices which hit record levels in China and as participants also digested the budget which included an upward revision to the first projected surplus in over a decade and proposed AUD 158bln in tax cuts. Japanese stocks were lifted as risk appetite was stimulated by reports US and China are nearing a final trade agreement with most issues resolved but continue to haggle on enforcement and implementation. Hang Seng (+1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) also benefitted from the trade hopes and after further encouraging data from China in which Caixin Services PMI topped estimates and printed its highest since January 2018. However, the performance of the mainland was somewhat fatigued after its recent bullish streak and with Bank of Communications underperforming on reports China National Council for Social Security Fund plans to sell 1.49bln of Bocom’s A-shares. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as trade hopes ensured a lack of safe-haven demand and with selling exacerbated as prices ran through stops at 153.00. SMBC also suggested the BoJ may reduce its purchases today, although this failed to materialize as the BoJ maintained its Rinban amounts which totalled JPY 1.23tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs and which helped alleviate some of the pressure.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7194 (Prev. 6.7161)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Mar) 54.4 vs. Exp. 52.3 (Prev. 51.1); Highest since January 2018 (Newswires)

Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Mar) 52.9 (Prev. 50.7)

US and China are drawing closer to a final trade agreement with most issues resolved although continue to haggle on trade deal enforcement and implementation. (FT)

UK/EU   

DUP said UK PM May's lamentable handling of negotiations with EU means she has failed to deliver a sensible Brexit, while it added it remains to be seen if sub-contracting out future of Brexit to Labour's Corbyn will end happily. (Newswires)

UK Tory Lawmaker Letwin says the process of seeking an Article 50 extension will go ahead as planned, adding that we can work with the government now; adds that Labour leader Corbyn is 'someone we can do business with' regarding Brexit., Telegraph's Swinford. (Twitter)

UK Labour MP Long-Bailey notes that leader Corbyn will not set red lines in talks with PM May. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Secretary Barclay says he personally thinks that a customs union is highly undesirable, Adds that labour does not have material objections to UK PM May's Withdrawal Agreement. And that there may be an "unpalatable" choice between no Brexit or a soft Brexit; expects a stable majority in Parliament for a Brexit deal if PM May and opposition leader Corbyn come to an agreement (Newswires)

UK PM May is said to consider asking lawmakers to rank Brexit outcomes. (Newswires)

EU is preparing to offer PM May a long Brexit extension with strict conditions including taking part in European Parliament elections and a possible “gentleman’s agreement” regarding Britain's conduct (e.g. potentially abstaining from taking part in important decisions over the EU’s future), according to FT. (FT/Twitter)

French President Macron has led other EU leaders in warning that UK PM May's apparent move to take no-deal Brexit off the table offers no guarantees UK will not crash out of the EU on April 12th. (Newswires)

EU Envoys have reportedly delayed approval of their mandate for US trade talks, according to sources. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Mar) 48.9 vs. Exp. 50.9 (Prev. 51.3)

Italian Markit/IHS Services PMI (Mar) 53.1 vs. Exp. 50.8 (Prev. 50.4)

EU Markit Comp Final PMI (Mar) 51.6 vs. Exp. 51.3 (Prev. 51.3)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are firmer [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.7%] as the positivity continues from overnight where sentiment was driven by US-China trade optimism and positive Chinese PMI data, although the FTSE 100 (Unch) is the exception to this with the index weighed on by the Brexit-related Sterling strength. Sector wise, material names (sector +1.5%) lead the gains as copper and iron prices are bolstered by the seemingly positive trade news alongside supply-side woes. On the flip side, healthcare names lag (sector -0.8%) with heavyweights Novartis (-1.0%) and Roche (-0.9%) weighed on by Walgreen’s cut in guidance yesterday. Elsewhere, the tech sector (+1.3%) is supported by advances in AMD yesterday (+3% pre-market) alongside Taiwan Semiconductor stating that they expect chip orders to pick up. 

Japan Display (6740 JT) are to reportedly supply Apple (AAPL) Watch OLED screens from this year, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

FX

DXY - This week’s risk roller-coaster continues, and the latest turn of the ride has lifted stocks and high beta currencies to the detriment of so-called safe havens, like the Dollar and core bonds. Hence, the Greenback has handed back gains made on Tuesday vs most G10 counterparts and EMs, with the index retreating towards 97.000 again from just over 97.500. The catalysts, another strong Chinese PMI and similar beats across the Eurozone/Europe, bar the UK, reports that the US and China are getting close to a trade agreement and Brexit developments raising prospects of some kind of deal as opposed to no deal.

AUD/NZD - The Aussie and Kiwi have benefited most from the resurgence in broad risk appetite, with the former also deriving independent impetus from data in the form of retail sales and trade overnight. Aud/Usd has recovered from near 2019 lows to 0.7100+, but may be hampered by more hefty option expiry interest as 1.6 bn runs off between 0.7100-10 at the NY cut. Meanwhile, Nzd/Usd is hovering just below 0.6800 compared to sub-0.6750 at worst as the Aud/Nzd cross holds close to the upper end of a 1.0495-50 range.

EUR/GBP/CAD/CHF - All firmer vs the Usd following underperformance yesterday, with the single currency boosted by better than expected Eurozone services PMIs across the board and marginally topping Tuesday’s 1.1250 peak, but capped by layered off said to be sitting up to 1.1270. Cable tested the water and resistance into 1.3200 on the back of the aforementioned Brexit manoeuvres aimed at reaching a pact to trigger an extension from April 12 that could lead to a softer withdrawal agreement or terms. However, the Pound was derailed to a degree by a significantly weaker than forecast UK services PMI as the headline recoiled below 50 and IHS predicted this means Q1 GDP stagnation before a downturn in H2. The Loonie continues to recoup losses vs its US peer post-contrasting manufacturing PMIs/ISM on Monday with the aid of firmer crude prices and the overall rebound in risk sentiment to probe over 1.3300, while the Franc is back up around 0.9960 from parity at one stage on Tuesday, but softer vs the Eur within 1.1177-1.1208 trading parameters after more dovish/intervention talk from the SNB.

SEK/NOK - The Scandi Crowns are still tracking broader swings in risk, along with technical and fundamental impulses, as Eur/Sek and Eur/Nok retreat towards recent lows and chart support levels circa 10.4100 and 9.6000 respectively.

EM - The Lira remains embroiled in political uncertainty as the main parties wrangle over regional election results against the backdrop of renewed diplomatic angst between Turkey and the US, while latest inflation data has piled more pressure on the Try and CBRT given a firmer than forecast CPI rate. Unsurprisingly, Usd/Try is holding above 5.6100 vs other Usd/regional pairings that are reversing recent rallies, and even the Rand in wake of a weak SA services PMI.

Australian Trade Balance (Mar) 4.80B vs. Exp. 3.80B (Prev. 4.55B, Rev. 4.35B). (Newswires) Australian Retail Sales (Mar) M/M 0.8% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%)

Head of Turkey's Electoral Board says votes in eight districts in Istanbul will be recounted following objections. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

The post-UK PMI bounce in bonds was relatively short-lived as the bulk of the March services PMIs (and manufacturing earlier) have eased fears of a deeper and more prolonged downturn in the global economy, albeit with the caveat that one month alone does not constitute a sea-change. Indeed, Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries have subsequently slipped to fresh intraday lows and/or tested previously established session troughs, with the 10 year EU debt futures down to 165.26 and 128.29 respectively. Ahead, ADP will be eyed as ever for NFP pointers, and the US PMI/ISM surveys to see if the forecast-beating run can resume after the CIPS/IHS Markit blip. Note also, a couple of Fed speakers and ECB’s de Cos to come.

COMMODITIES

Commodities are largely on the front foot amidst the overall risk appetite couple with a falling buck. WTI (+0.1%) and Brent (+0.6%) futures have been grinding higher since last night, shrugging off the surprise build in API crude stocks (+3.0mln vs. Exp. -0.4mln) with the former residing just above USD 62.60/bbl having hit resistance at USD 63.00/bbl. The support the oil complex has seen has mostly been due to supply disruptions rather than demand improvement. Traders will be eyeing the DoE release today, although price action may be muted as Iranian and Venezuelan supply woes/ market risk appetite hold onto the spotlight.

Elsewhere, metals across the board are benefiting from the easing buck with spot gold (+0.1%) remaining below USD 1300/oz (for now), whilst copper (+1.2%) surges on trade optimism after reports that US and China are inching closer to a deal, with the Chinese trade delegation heading to Washington today for another round of talks. Furthermore, Barclays noted that copper supply-side disruptions have the potential to boost the red metal to USD 7000/tonne. Finally, Dalian iron ore prices were bolstered to record highs, also hit by supply issues, as damage is calculated from the cyclones in Western Australia. Barclays also raised its 2019 iron ore price forecast to USD 75/tonne (Prev. USD 69/tonne).

Barclays says copper supply-side disruptions have the potential to boost the red metal to USD 7000/tonne; separately, raised its 2019 iron ore price forecast to USD 75/tonne (Prev. USD 69/tonne). (Newswires)

ARA region crude inventories rose 375k barrels to 60mlm in the week ending March 29th., according to Genscape. (Newswires)

ECB allots USD 54.8mln in 7-day USD op.
Fixed Income: UK services PMI contracts and counters buoyant trend
content: In stark contrast to Monday’s much stronger than forecast manufacturing survey (with mitigating Brexit factors admittedly), the sub-50 UK services PMI has thrown a spanner in the works following better than expected non-manufacturing surveys kicking off in China and continuing through the Eurozone and the rest of Europe. Hence, a firmer rebound in Gilts from a slightly deeper 128.37 Liffe trough, but still lagging/underperforming Bunds that have also pared losses from 165.32 having tested, though not broken chart support around 165.34. Elsewhere, US Treasuries remain close to overnight session lows and the curve is fully back in steepening mode ahead of ADP and the US services PMI/ISM combo.

subject: Brexit Secretary Barclay says that there may be an "unpalatable" choice between no Brexit or a soft Brexit; expects a stable majority in Parliament for a Brexit deal if PM May and opposition leader Corbyn come to an agreement

German engineering orders -10% in February Y/Y (foreign -16%), according to VDMA
Kuwait oil refinery production exports are normal following a fire at the Mina Abdullah refinery
SGH Macro on the possibility of tiered rates at the ECB
content:
• Tiering rates will be raised at the upcoming Governing Council meeting on April 10, but with the uncertainty of Brexit looming just ahead and no strong consensus yet on the need for it, no decision will be made then. 
  • It will be studied and kept in reserve either to be rolled out with a new TLTRO-3 program, or perhaps even later in the year, if and when Draghi may need to extend forward guidance on negative rates beyond the end of 2019 and well into 2020.

subject: Commerzbank (CBK GY) Co. are to decide on April 9th whether to intensify or discontinue merger talks with Deutsche Bank (DBK GY)., according to Wiwo
Head of Turkey's Electoral Board says votes in eight districts in Istanbul will be recounted following objections
Gilts and Short Sterling futures acknowledging risk revival and 'bullish' Brexit vibes
content: A double or even triple whammy for UK debt and STIR contracts amidst a broader rebound in risk sentiment, as UK PM May’s climbdown and reach out to Labour for a way to find a Brexit breakthrough has sparked expectations that a compromise would result in a softer deal rather than no deal, or at the very least could be enough to trigger an A 50 extension from April 12 to May 22. The 10 year bond gapped down 76 ticks on its return to Liffe and hit 128.42 vs yesterday’s 129.33 close before finding some underlying bids and has subsequently bounced to 128.64, while the 3 month strip has been as much as 8 ticks below par, but not -6.5 ticks at worst. Gilts and Short Sterling contracts are now consolidating awaiting more news ahead of the services PMI and after meetings between the 2 party leaders, PMQs and what looks set to be another hectic day in Whitehall.

subject: Bunds: breaking to new week-to-date lows
content: A return to risk-on trade after another and even more impressive Chinese PMI beat, reports that US-China trade talks are nearing completion (albeit with the final 10% still proving tough to resolve and including key issues) and latest Brexit developments implying a softer withdrawal has hit core debt, with the 10 year German benchmark extending losses below 166.00 and from Tuesday’s 166.11 Eurex close. After a relatively modest initial markdown to 165.93 and brief recovery to 166.00, Bunds subsequently breached near term support around 165.70 and tripped some stops on the way down to Monday’s 165.60 session low and then more sell orders when that gave way. 165.47 is now the new weekly base and this is just a fraction off the next downside technical target at 165.45 before 165.34. Ahead, Eurozone services PMIs in focus before a late speech from ECB’s de Cos, while US ADP will be eyed as a pre-NFP proxy.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

3rd April 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as trade optimism and Chinese PMI data helped the region shrug-off the indecisive lead from the US, where the global stock rally had stalled amid thin volumes, weak durable goods data and ahead of upcoming risk events. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) were positive with Australia led by miners amid strength in iron ore prices which hit record levels in China and as participants also digested the budget which included an upward revision to the first projected surplus in over a decade and proposed AUD 158bln in tax cuts. Japanese stocks were lifted as risk appetite was stimulated by reports US and China are nearing a final trade agreement with most issues resolved but continue to haggle on enforcement and implementation. Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) also benefitted from the trade hopes and after further encouraging data from China in which Caixin Services PMI topped estimates and printed its highest since January 2018. However, the performance of the mainland was somewhat fatigued after its recent bullish streak and with Bank of Communications underperforming on reports China National Council for Social Security Fund plans to sell 1.49bln of Bocom’s A-shares.

FTSE

Paddy Power Betfair (PPB LN) – The gambling watchdog has forced Co. remove two games over concerns they undermine a crackdown on addictive betting machines. (Telegraph)

Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN) – No issues were found in Singapore, following yesterday’s grounding of jets due to reported engine issues. (Newswires)

BT (BT/A LN) – Co’s union Prospect, which is one of the largest, has rejected the Co’s restructuring plans, stating they would install a ‘extreme cultural change’ on the Co. 96% of the unions surveyed staff reportedly opposed the Co’s plans. (FT)

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. are leaving the American Fuel & Petrochemical Manufacturers trade association, due to the group’s opposition to prices on greenhouse emissions such as a carbon tax. (FT)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – Following European regulators outlining their set of objections regarding the Co’s proposed takeover of Liberty Global, none of these objections have been described as being a ‘deal breaker’, according to reports citing someone with direct knowledge. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Provident Financial (PFG LN)/ Non-Standard Finance (NSF LN) – The takeover battle between Cos have escalated after Provident Financial raised questions about NSF’s past dividend pay-outs. (FT/Telegraph) 

BROKER MOVES

DCC (DCC LN) INITATED WITH BUY AT JEFFERIES

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Co. has teamed up with Khloris to develop Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells as breakthrough anti-cancer vaccines. (Newswires)

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – Analysts at MoffettNathanson said the odds of a T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S) merger has dropped to 33% (Prev. 50%) due to US states’ apparently willingness to fight the USD 26bln merger. Deutsche Telekom owns 63.5% of T-Mobile. (Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) – March US sales +0.4% Y/Y to 35.997k vehicles. Separately, co. have ended their plans for comprehensive development cooperation with Mercedes Benz, according to reports. (Newswires)

Daimler (DAI GY) – Mercedes/Smart March US sales -2.7% Y/Y to 30.627k vehicles. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – March US sales +14% Y/Y to 37.092k vehicles. Audi March US sales +1.1% Y/Y to 20.3k vehicles. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co.’s US arm reportedly handled some of at least USD 150bln in transactions for a small Estonian unit of Danske Bank (DANSKE DC), as flagged up by a former compliance officer. (Newswires) 

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Metro (B4B GY) – Co. are still in talks with potential suitors who are interested in purchasing Co.’s Real hypermarkets chain. A spokesman said the Co. was in talks with more than two serious investors. It was earlier reported that two investors both made offers of around EUR 900mln for the unit, according to sources. (Newswires)

Porsche (PAH3 GY) – March US sales +0.5% to 4.779k vehicles. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Orange (ORA FP) – Co’s CEO has received support from both investors and unions following French prosecutors demanding he be sentenced to 3 years in prison, for allegations regarding fraud. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Generali (G IM) – Co.’s top investor, Mediobanca (MB IM) is proposing to confirm Co’s CEO Donnet and Chairman Galateri in current positions. (Newswires)

Mediaset (MS IM) – CEO noted the Co. is still studying possible cross-border deal but said “it’s not just up to us”. (Newswires)

Snam (SRG IM) – Marco Alvera has been confirmed as the Co’s CEO and Luca Del Fabbro has been appointed as the Co’s Chairman. (Newswires)

SMI

Julius Baer (BAER SW) – Co. shares will be dropped out of the SMI and replaced with Novartis’ (NOVN SW) spin-off Alcon as of April 10th. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SWISS RE (SREN SW) REITERATED OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

SCANDINAVIA

Pandora (PNDORA DC) – Co’s COO Jeremy Schwartz is to resign with immediate effect, following mutual agreement with the Co’s board. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

US

* SPX +0.00% at 2867, NDX +0.28% at 7500, DJI -0.30% at 16180. SECTORS: Energy -0.70%, Materials +0.40%, Industrials -0.06%, Cons Discretionary -0.02%, Cons Staples -0.84%, Healthcare -0.24%, Financials -0.01%, Tech +0.30%, Telecoms +0.40%, Utilities +0.11%, Communications +0.54%.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 3rd April 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian indices were firmer with sentiment driven by Chinese PMIs and US-China trade; ahead of further talks in Washington
  • UK PM May seeks a further A50 extension and a solution with Labour leader Corbyn
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ, UK & US Services PMIs, EZ Retail Sales, US ADP National Employment, US Non-Manufacturing ISM PMI, Fed's Bostic, Barkin, George & Kashkari

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as trade optimism and Chinese PMI data helped the region shrug-off the indecisive lead from the US, where the global stock rally had stalled amid thin volumes, weak durable goods data and ahead of upcoming risk events. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) were positive with Australia led by miners amid strength in iron ore prices which hit record levels in China and as participants also digested the budget which included an upward revision to the first projected surplus in over a decade and proposed AUD 158bln in tax cuts. Japanese stocks were lifted as risk appetite was stimulated by reports US and China are nearing a final trade agreement with most issues resolved but continue to haggle on enforcement and implementation. Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) also benefitted from the trade hopes and after further encouraging data from China in which Caixin Services PMI topped estimates and printed its highest since January 2018. However, the performance of the mainland was somewhat fatigued after its recent bullish streak and with Bank of Communications underperforming on reports China National Council for Social Security Fund plans to sell 1.49bln of Bocom’s A-shares. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as trade hopes ensured a lack of safe-haven demand and with selling exacerbated as prices ran through stops at 153.00. SMBC also suggested the BoJ may reduce its purchases today, although this failed to materialize as the BoJ maintained its Rinban amounts which totalled JPY 1.23tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs and which helped alleviate some of the pressure.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7194 (Prev. 6.7161)

 

Chinese Caixin Services PMI (Mar) 54.4 vs. Exp. 52.3 (Prev. 51.1); Highest since January 2018 (Newswires)

Chinese Caixin Composite PMI (Mar) 52.9 (Prev. 50.7)

US and China are drawing closer to a final trade agreement with most issues resolved although continue to haggle on trade deal enforcement and implementation. (FT)

US Chamber of Commerce official said US-China trade talks are at a point where a deal is more likely than not. The official also commented that negotiators from both sides need to make progress on enforcement mechanism as well as tariff removal issues this week and commented that it is unlikely China would agree to the trade agreement enforcement mechanism with unilateral US right to retaliation unless all US tariffs on Chinese goods are first withdrawn. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May said we need a further extension of A50 to ensure we leave in a timely way with a deal and will try to complete legislation by May 22nd. PM May said she is taking action to break the logjam and offered to sit down with opposition Labour leader Corbyn to hopefully reach a solution that delivers on the referendum and if they cannot agree on a single unified approach, they could agree on a set of arrangements to put to the house and that the government would abide by Parliament’s decision. There were later reports that PM May is said to consider asking lawmakers to rank Brexit outcomes. (Newswires)

UK PM May spokesperson said the UK is setting a course where we hope it won't be necessary to participate in the EU Parliament elections and commented that it is possible to cancel participation right up to the day of those elections. (Newswires)

DUP said UK PM May's lamentable handling of negotiations with EU means she has failed to deliver a sensible Brexit, while it added it remains to be seen if sub-contracting out future of Brexit to Labour's Corbyn will end happily. (Newswires)

EU is preparing to offer PM May a long Brexit extension with strict conditions including taking part in European Parliament elections and a possible “gentleman’s agreement” regarding Britain's conduct (e.g. potentially abstaining from taking part in important decisions over the EU’s future), according to FT. Separately, EU officials are said to think the UK could get an extension with a pretty weak excuse *as long as* it signs up to terms and conditions such as European elections and more, according to Guardian's Jennifer Rankin. (FT/Guardian/Twitter)

French President Macron has led other EU leaders in warning that UK PM May's apparent move to take no-deal Brexit off the table offers no guarantees UK will not crash out of the EU on April 12th. (Newswires)

A senior EU official said the WA would need to be approved by MPs next week - if the UK doesn’t participate EP elections - because otherwise a short extension is “not imaginable” as it would “jeopardise” elections, according to BuzzFeed. (Twitter)

UK BRC Shop Price Index (Mar) Y/Y 0.9% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the greenback weakened as it suffered from the broad strength seen across its major counterparts including EUR/USD which rebounded to back above the 1.1200 level, while GBP/USD held firm after PM May announced she will seek a further extension to Article 50 and offered to sit down with opposition Labour leader Corbyn to find a solution for the current deadlock. Furthermore, PM May is aiming to complete legislation by May 22nd and suggested if they cannot reach a single unified approach, they could agree on a set of arrangements to put to the house and that the government would abide by Parliament’s decision. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were lifted by the risk appetite, while antipodeans also benefitted from their high-beta properties with AUD/USD further boosted by better than expected Australian Retail Sales and Trade Surplus, as well as the Chinese PMI data, which saw the pair test resistance at 0.7100 where there is also a large option expiry of AUD 1.3bln for today’s New York cut.

Australian Trade Balance (Mar) 4.80B vs. Exp. 3.80B (Prev. 4.55B, Rev. 4.35B). (Newswires) Australian Retail Sales (Mar) M/M 0.8% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%) COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mostly higher in which WTI crude futures marginally extended on gains to its best levels in around 5 months with prices underpinned by the positive risk sentiment and ongoing supply side factors with the US also looking to take further action on the Venezuela’s Maduro regime. Elsewhere, upside in gold was restricted as the gains in stocks weighed on safe-havens, while copper benefitted from the risk tone and amid further upside in Chinese iron ore prices which hit fresh all-time highs amid  tightening supply concerns and expectations of increased demand from steel mills.  

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (29 March): +3.0mln (Exp. -0.4mln, prev. +1.9mln). (Newswires)

US VP Pence said the US is looking to take action to isolate Venezuela's Maduro regime, while there were also reports that Venezuela exported nearly 1mln BPD in March despite sanctions and power outages according to PDVSA. (Newswires)

US ITC finds some imports of large-diameter welded steel pipe from Canada, Greece, South Korea and Turkey harm domestic producers, locking in duties; says some other pipe imports do not. Elsewhere, it was also reported that Russia has notified the WTO that it may retaliate for EU steel curbs. (Newswires/IFX) 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said he gets along great with North Korean leader Kim but added he is not ready for a deal, while there were separate reports that North Korea propaganda outlet criticized South Korea's cautious approach to inter-Korean relations in which it suggested Seoul has given in to US pressure. (Newswires)

 

US

Action was rangebound and horizontal, with a bias higher with risk-sentiment cooling after Monday’s PMI/ISM inspired bounce. The complex managed to look through the US data; after UK PM May’s remarks, which points to a softer form of Brexit, Treasuries saw small downside as US stocks saw positive ticks. Major curve spreads were relatively unchanged at settlement. US T-note futures (M9) settled 5 ticks higher at 123-24+.

US President Trump said Germany is not paying its fair share to NATO and repeated his threat that he is prepared to close the border with Mexico if he has to, while there were also comments from US NEC Director Kudlow that the US is looking at ways to allow freight passage if the US-Mexico border shuts. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed United States sovereign rating at 'AAA'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks are lifted on trade hopes and Chinese PMI data
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly higher as trade optimism and Chinese PMI data helped the region shrug-off the indecisive lead from US where the global stock rally stalled amid thin volumes, weak durable goods data and ahead of upcoming risk events. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) are positive with Australia led by miners amid strength in iron ore prices which hit record levels in China and with participants also digesting the budget which included an upward revision to the first projected surplus in over a decade and a proposed AUD 158bln in tax cuts. Meanwhile, Japanese stocks shrugged off early indecision as risk appetite was stimulated by reports US and China are nearing a final trade agreement with most issues resolved but continue to haggle on enforcement and implementation. Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) benefitted from the trade hopes and after further encouraging data from China in which Caixin Services PMI topped estimates and printed its highest since January 2018, but with the mainland somewhat flimsy following its recent bullish streak.

In FX markets, the greenback is weaker as it suffers from the broad strength seen across its major counterparts including EUR/USD which has rebounded to back above the 1.1200 level, while GBP/USD holds firm after PM May announced she will seek a further extension to Article 50 and offered to sit down with opposition Labour leader Corbyn to find a solution for the current deadlock. Furthermore, PM May is aiming to complete legislation by May 22nd and suggested if they cannot reach a single unified approach, they could agree on a set of arrangements to put to the house and that the government would abide by Parliament’s decision. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are lifted by the risk appetite, while antipodeans also benefit from their high-beta properties with AUD/USD further boosted by better than expected Australian Retail Sales and Trade Surplus as well as the Chinese PMI data, which saw the pair test resistance at the 0.7100 level where there is also a large option expiry of AUD 1.3bln for today’s New York cut.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower with prices retreating on the US-China trade hopes and with selling exacerbated as prices ran through stops at 153.00, while SMBC had also suggested the BoJ may reduce its purchases. However, JGBs are off their worst level with some mild support also seen after the BoJ maintained its Rinban amounts which totalled JPY 1.23tln in 1yr-10yr JGBs.
